items.author: Desson Thomson
items.content: Polanski, himself a survivor of Nazi-occupied Poland, has created a near-masterpiece.

items.author: Ty Burr
items.content: There are three Poles in The Pianist -- Szpilman, Polanski, and Frederic Chopin. Of the three, fittingly, Chopin speaks the loudest.

items.author: Lisa Schwarzbaum
items.content: The result is a movie, and Cannes Palme d'Or winner, of riveting power and sadness, a great match of film and filmmaker -- and star, too.

items.author: Jonathan Rosenbaum
items.content: The results are masterful, admirably unsentimental, and never boring, if also a little stodgy.

items.author: David Ansen
items.content: This powerful, precision-made movie offers hope as well -- an act of kindness from a German officer that saves the pianistÂ’s life, the music that sustains his soul.

items.author: Manohla Dargis
items.content: Never before has a fiction film so clearly and to such devastating effect laid out the calculation of the Nazi machinery of death and its irrationality.

items.author: Marc Savlov
items.content: Szpilman takes to performing sonatas in thin air, eyes closed, those jittery fingers stroking nothing but air. It's a wonderful moment in a wonderful, ghastly film, and one of the most moving arguments for the redemptive powers of art ever made.

items.author: Ken Fox
items.content: Polanski's film is an unqualified success both dramatically and artistically.

items.author: Stanley Kauffmann
items.content: To name only one of its predecessors -- for me, the towering one -- doesn't "Schindler's List" do everything that Polanski achieves and more?

items.author: Scott Tobias
items.content: Through Brody's remarkably controlled, self-effacing performance, Polanski succeeds in making his hero an invisible man, but the sights he conjures are surprisingly artless and ordinary, familiar from a dozen other Holocaust dramas. Among the casualties in The Pianist is a great director's imagination.
